column10: b'b" Randi and Gina
column11: Gina-a couple of design Qs for you below. Randi
column12: will email you separately about a few other things. Looks like a great start! On 2 Jul
column14: at 10:41 PM
column15: randi2kewl wrote:re: checking the link
column16: I think it will make sense to check links up to at least a week after posting
column17: maybe even longer (say a month).  Activity on these links sometimes goes in cycles if a post is RTd later. To get the age of the link
column18: it seems fine to get the date from the associated post. (The same link could be associated w/ multiple posts but that\'s okay in this context). In terms of tracking the  links: because we want to do periodic checks
column19: it could make sense to keep bookkeeping as plugin \'instance\'  data
column20: similar to the data in the tu_instances_twitter table.  This lets us work progressively from oldest to newest candidate link
column21: doing a configurable chunk of work each crawler run from where we left off last time
column22: and then cycle back to recheck starting with the links from e.g. a month previous to the current date. Gina does this approach (using instance data bookkeeping) make sense to you?  If so
column23: I think we would want to create a new instances table for this plugin (e.g. \'tu_instances_expandurls\')?"'

column10: b'b\' On Sun
column11: Jul 3
column13: amygdalareply@wrote:Makes sense. So
column14: it would be something like a "Last update" field
column15: andif it\\\'s older than a month
column16: that triggers the crawler to go back andrefresh again?Yes
column17: it does. We would use a tu_instances_expandurls table to doinstance-level tracking
column18: because it left joins onto tu_instances. I\\\'mhaving trouble imagining how we\\\'d do this bookkeeping on aper-instance level
column19: versus a per-link level. What would the fields be? ##  url url \''

column10: b'b" For the instance fields
column11: one approach would be to keep two pieces of information-the timestamp of when we last \'finished checking\' the links
column12: and a \'cursor\' timestamp indicating where we stopped work on the last crawler run. With this information we could do something like the following.Each time the crawler runs
column13: do two things:process N1 of the links [those with no ]
column14: oldest first
column15: also expanding them as necessary. For this part
column16: we don\'t need to keep any instance information as long as we work up through the links chronologically.recheck N2 of the already-processed bitly links as follows.  Each time the crawler runs
column17: first see if the \'cursor\' value is 0.  If it is
column18: test the \'finished_checking\' date. If it is < 6 hours ago (or some reasonable configurable value)
column19: just exit.  This prevents constant rechecking
column20: which is probably not necessary.  If the cursor == 0 and \'finished_checking\' is Then fetch N2 links with date >= the cursor date.  After processing the N2 items
column21: set the cursor to the date where we left off.  When we run out of items
column22: set the cursor = 0 and \'finished_checking\' to the current time."'

column10: b"b' url '"
b'b\' To recreate:[1]  In your browser
column11: log in to your Twitter account (say @first)[2] Set up new TU instance[3]  connect your TU instance to Twitter for your first user
column12: and set it to spider @first in the usual way.[4] log out of TU (but NOT Twitter) and set up your second TU user.[5] Log in to TU as the second user
column13: and [6] attempt to hook in a Twitter account for this second user (e.g. @second) Voila the "oid" error. Workaround: Log out of Twitter (be sure to delete the cookies for  I found the login to be oddly persistent)Repeat step [6] above
column14: and all is good. I can\\\'t say that this happens ONLY in fresh instances of TU.  Guesses:[A] The TU->Twitter account authorization process expects the browser to be logged out of Twitter (probably not) [B] a given Twitter account can only be hooked to a single TU user in a given TU instance.\''

b"b' Use timezone instead of UTC offset if possible'"
b'b" Set the time_zone session variable in MySQL to a timezone
column11: e.g.
column12: instead of the current offset.  This fixesconversion  UTC for times that are in a different offset. For example
column14: Los Angeles is -07:00 because it is daylightsaving time.  If you store 2011-01-01 00:00:00 into a TIMESTAMP fieldwhen your time_zone session variable is set to \'-07:00\'
column15: the time willbe stored as 2011-01-01 07:00:00 UTC instead of 2011-01-01 08:00:00
column16: which will be used if your time_zone variable is set to\'\'. Using timezones instead of offsets requires that the MySQL timezonetables be populated.  See mysql_tzinfo_to_sql(1).  If a timezone can\'tbe used
column17: fall back to using an offset."'

column10: b'b" To fully test this
column11: you need to run the test with the timezone tables both empty and populated
column12: and during DST and outside of DST. Truncate the timezone tables. Tests should fail because we can\'t set the time_zone session variable correctly Populate the timezone tables Now the tests will succeed  "'

column10: b"b' Fix looks good
column11: Christian
column12: but this test is failing on my local dev machine (PST): ada:thinkup gina$ php 1) Equal expectation fails at character 6 with [1293865200] and [1293868800] at [/ line 351]  in testCompareMySQLAndPHPTimezoneOffsets  in TestOfPDODAOFAILURES!!!Test cases run: 1/3
column13: Passes: 118
column14: Failures: 1
column15: Exceptions: 0'"

column10: b'b" Is it failing with the MySQL time_zone tables populated?  It should fail if these tables aren\'t populated and you run the test during daylight savings time because your MySQL connection will be set to UTC-7
column11: but PHP will know that times on 2011-01-01 should be calculated as UTC-8. The timestamp you\'re getting for the MySQL connection indicates that UTC-7 is being used. Perhaps instead of falling back to an offset if a timezone can\'t be set
column12: the time_zone session variable should be set to SYSTEM so the server\'s time zone is used.  Or should the test be written to succeed when the timezone can\'t be set properly?  Long term
column13: ThinkUp should either require that the \\\\* tables be populated in order support time zones other than the server\'s
column14: or store everything in UTC in the database and do the time zone conversion in PHP."'

column10: b'b" Yeah
column11: looks like the time_zone tables aren\'t populated: Once I populate them
column12: that test passes
column13: but another fails: The test shouldn\'t require that the timezones are loaded to pass; if they weren\'t on my Mac I can assume they won\'t be in a lot of other dev environments and we don\'t want to make setting up the tests any more difficult for developers. Can the test check to see whether or not the timezone tables are loaded and assert accordingly?"'

column10: b'b" Since the thinkup user probably doesn\'t have access to the \\\\* tables
column11: I try to set the time zone and catch failures."'

b'b\' Hi Gina
column11: I request you to review my fork where I\\\'ve realised some modifications or adds.I have made it because I needed to extract some information from the ThinkUp tables in a range of time using the ThinkUp API. I add some functions to achieve it. Those functions are:Post_replies_in_rangeUser_replies_in_rangeUser_questions_in_rangeUser_mentions_in_range Those functions required arguments: from and until. The way to capture this data is the same way as user_posts_in_range. url  I saw in this documentation that to specify the date
column12: it should be done in European format (dd-mm-yyyy) but I tried to do it and I saw that it\\\'s necessary to write date in American Format and adding extra information depending of the time zone. To capture correctly this data
column13: I use the format : "YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:IIGMT+02:00". I hope you contact me if my explanation is not correct. Best wishes
column14: Daniel Pe\\xc3\\xb1a Pizarro\''

column10: b'b\' Replicated this on a fresh under Windows Vista (we are out there) 32-bit.  The commas ( ) and equal signs ( ) are valid filename characters and the string lengths are under the 255 character limit. Normally when you grab files that contain invalid characters Windows will just automatically delete it for you and leave you with a need to commit something. Looks like the filename and folder lengths are too long. By the time you get to the file you stop here: application_rate_limit_-resources=account

JackTandy" notifications@ wrote:\''
ThinkUp	1519	closed	11	gavinr	2013-03-26 18:57:45	655.67		+1		b"b' Gina, It looks like two offending files (at least for me) are in this directory:url  That directory plus filename is approx 240 characters, and it appears that Windows 7 (even 64-bit) has a 256 character limit url  so if someone has his or her git repo in a location that has over 16 characters, there will be problems.  My repo, for example, is at:  ... which is causing problems because that path is 258 characters. I tested shortening the path to C:\\\\g\\\\ThinkUp\\\\webapp..... and the problems went away for me, so I do believe the 256-character limit is the issue. tl;dr we need to shorten the path lengths for the twitter test data Thanks!!'

column10: b"b' How about we advise Windows-based developers to use folder names under 16 characters in our documentation?'"
b'b\' Hmm
column11: it\\\'s your project to do as you see fit
column12: however
column13: in my opinion this is a terrible work-around
column14: albeit better than nothing
column15: and definitely the **only one** of many projects from  or bazaar repos that has this filename issue. To pass the responsibility to the installer instead of addressing the issue properly by reducing the filename length is may i say poor. Also
column16: I am not even talking about the install stage
column17: simply cloning the repo to a folder greater than 16 chars is all that is required to raise this issue. Does..."application_rate_limit_-resources=account
column34: search" really add value as file names on any OS? The longest name here is 133 chars
column36: how about renaming it to 16 so win has 133 chars? Perhaps
column38: is the resistance to rename due to the file name (and this would be shocking) being used as parameters to a function. Please reconsider
column39: much preferable are shorter meaningful file names that can be neatly organized in sub folders rather than the ancient 1990s practice of things requiring to be placed at drive root (as per the docs suggestion) yuk! Thanks\''

column10: b'b" @JackTandy each of those files represents the payload of an API call which developers use to write automated tests for code which make those calls to actual URLs when the app is running. The filenames look odd because they map simply and clearly to URLs with specific parameters defined by third-party APIs
column11: in this case Twitter\'s. Shortening them would add yet another level of mapping that developers would have to decode while they write tests. My job is to make writing tests easier
column12: not more difficult
column13: hence the more  filenames. The files lengths are well within Windows\' 256-character limit. We\'re not asking devs to store the files at the root
column14: just within a 16-character folder name. I realize that is short. What do you suggest ThinkUp\'s max file length should be? 200? 225?"'

column10: b'b" Tricky to say without looking at relevant use code
column11: perhaps create stubs...application_rate_limit_-resources=accountapplication_rate_limit_-resources=statuses...application_rate_limit_-resources=search and if this doesn\'t fit
column12: and in all honesty
column13: the mapping **should** be refactored. File names should never be used as function parameters for all manner of reasons e.g. scalability."'

column10: b'b" Digging into this a bit more
column11: I recall that we do (attempt) to enforce a 200-character file length for mock test data. See url  for the code which is supposed to do that. Turns out the command is only checking the filename
column12: not the path AND the filename
column13: so these files got in past it. I\'m working on a fix for both the command and shortening the folder names so that Windows devs will have to stay under a 56-character limit pathwise
column14: which seems more reasonable than 16."'

column10: b'b\' @ginatrapani Yup
column11: a 56 char limit is a **far** better proposition than 16. Thanks for sorting this. I can confirm thinkapp now clones without issue into a "reasonable" path on windows where in my use case
column12: the base path cloned into is... X:_incoming\\\\Internet\\\\Twitter\\\\ThinkUp\\\\ A virtual chocolate muffin and a high five to Gina.\''

This array would be loaded with each Insight instance and can contain terms like:$network_term[\\\'post_noun\\\'] = "tweet
column13: status update

column20:
+1\\\'ed"...etc\''
ThinkUp	1622	closed	7	ginatrapani	2013-05-28 18:31:28	458.98		+1		b'b" Let\'s make it as modular as possible. How about a new class, InsightTerms, that has a set of static functions, such as getPostTerm, getPastTenseLikeTerm, getPastTensePostedTerm, etc.  Each of those functions should return the right term based on a given network. Then we can easily test each function and just call it where needed inside insights, InsightTerms::getPostTerm($network). How does that sound?"'
ThinkUp	1622	closed	8	nilakshdas	2013-05-28 18:31:28	1276.28			+1	b'b" This sounds good in terms of modularity but don\'t you think we would be complicating things if we have to type InsightTerms::getPostTerm($instance->network) just to get \'tweets\' every time? How about initializing InsightTerms with the network parameter in InsightPluginParent itself? And instead of having methods, we treat InsightTerms as just a data structure. The constructor can load all the member variables according to the given network parameter. Or we can also instantiate insight_terms of anonymous type within InsightPluginParent with getInsightTerms(). Since insight terms are only intrinsic to insights, should we really create a whole class for it? Don\'t you think InsightPluginParent should encapsulate this data internally?For testing, we can create a TestOfInsightPluginParent."'
ThinkUp	1622	closed	9	ginatrapani	2013-05-28 18:31:28	341.9		+1		b'b\' This is similar to how gettext() works, a localization library for PHP. In a way, this is a kind of network localization.Sure, we can do that. So in InsightPluginParent::__construct, we could have a $this->terms = new InsightTerms($instance->network). But we\\\'d still have an InsightTerms object in that case.Do you mean that InsightPluginParent would have member variables, like $post_term, $liked_term, $published_term? We could initialize those either using an InsightsTerm object, or a private associative array inside the InsightPluginParent class. I\\\'m advocating for the separate class for modularity\\\'s sake. I thought you were suggesting we have a giant public associative array, which would require the internal insight code (or at least the InsightParentPlugin constructor) to have intimate knowledge of the structure of this array to access the terms.  Best practices for good OOP design generally suggest creating getter methods which abstract away data structures internally, so that we could make changes to it later without having to refactor the calling code. (And there will be  soon, for YouTube.) It sounds like the question is do we put this  logic in the InsightPluginParent or in a new InsightTerms class. I like to keep classes small, specific, and make them do "one thing well
column21: so I tend toward creating new classes for small jobs like this. It makes for cleaner
column23: code where each classes\\\' job is apparent. This is a good . We could go either way
column24: but ultimately I think a separate class is the best OOP code design.\''

column10: b'b" I meant adding a getInsightTerms() function to InsightPluginParent that would return an object of anonymous class whose member variables would be the required data. And this data could be loaded into $this->terms.You\'re right! Reading this
column11: I just realized that insight terms are in no way a sub-property of InsightPluginParent. So it makes more sense to have a separate class that well defines its functionality. In terms of abstraction
column12: we\'re making it available to the insight through $this->terms in any case. One more thing
column13: does it make more sense to have member methods like getNoun(\'post\')
column14: getNoun(\'like\')
column15: getVerb(\'posted\')
column16: getVerb(\'liked\') which could then return the data directly or call private functions like getPostTerm() etc. This way it is more intuitive for the developer to build the insight language."'

b'b\' Hi Nilaksh! Now that we have our insight style guide
column11: I keep realizing better ways we can word insights
column12: including this one. Here\\\'s an example I\\\'ve seen: Metweets:  @soandso retweeted posts mentioning themself 2 times in the last week. We want to avoid using "themself"
column13: and it would be good to localize "posts" to tweets (though it may sound redundant after "retweeted"). Would be nice to also convert 2 times to twice
column14: for that conversational feel we\\\'re looking for: What do you think about this? Metweets:  @soandso retweeted tweets mentioning @soandso twice last week.\''

column10: b"b' Another possibility:  Metweets: @soandso retweeted @soandso mentions  twice last week.'"
b"b' Another way of wording the first example could be:Which one do you think we should go with?'"
b'b" Let\'s avoid passive voice. It\'s less conversational. Let\'s go with: Metweets: username retweeted username mentions twice last week."'

column10: b'b\' ![gina_trapani_s_thinkup-2 2]url  Hi Nilaksh I\\\'m starting to see this insight on my installation now. It looks great! There are a couple of things I think we should do to make it a little more conversational
column11: and match the editorial style of existing insights.  First
column12: always use the numeric version of numbers versus the word version
column13: but the current copy mixes both ("1" and "one.")  Next
column14: to make the insight more conversational
column15: when the number before the time interval is 1 we can just say "every hour" or "every day"
column16: versus "every 1 hour." Finally
column18: we can drop the "new" in "new comment" and "over the" in "over the last week."  With those changes
column19: the first example in the screenshot would read: ginatrapani\\\'s tweets averaged 1 reply every hour last week
column20: faster than the previous week\\\'s average of 1 reply every 2 hours. [Bold "1 reply every hour"] The second example would read: ginatrapani\\\'s checkins averaged 1 comment every day last week
column21: faster than the previous week\\\'s average of 1 comment every 7 days. [Bold "1 comment every day"] Let me know what you think. Apologies for being so nitpicky

column10: b"b' Like Spike Insight'"
b"b' Hi
column11: As we discussed here is the Like Spike insight
column12: highlighting videos with all time highs and peaks over the average for 30 / 90 / 365 days. ![screenshot from 2013-08-26 18 19 02]url ![screenshot from 2013-08-26 18 18 53]url  It also adds a method to convert numerical multipliers to a string as per the insight guidelines and also includes methods to generate the hot videos charts for any attribute.'"

column10: b"b' Changes discussed above are now part of this commit.'"
b'b\' Hi Aaron
column11: This commit combines different changes into one diff: the InsightTerms modifications
column12: and the insight. When you can
column13: separate discrete changes like this into separate commits for easier review. The insight needs some work
column14: but @nilakshdas needs the InsightTerms changes to proceed with his development
column15: so I broke out the InsightTerms modifications and reviewed those first. I made some changes to your implementation and wanted to explain them here: First
column16: I combined getMultiplierAdverb and getMultiplierDecreaseAdverb. I didn\\\'t see any reason why those couldn\\\'t be the same function. The advantage of combining them is that it decreases the number of possible valid values for $type from 3 to 2 (no more \\\'multiplier-decrease\\\'). Then I noticed that $number could be a string (for getOccurrencesAdverb) or an int the rest of the time
column17: which doesn\\\'t make sense. All of these functions convert a number to a term
column18: so they should all only accept ints. So I modified getOccurrencesAdverb to accept ints only. Then we were down to 3 function
column19: one public function getNumberTerm which took a parameter $type to route the logic to one of two private functions. This didn\\\'t make sense to me. So I deleted the public function and simply made the two private functions public. This way the call to the function only takes 1 parameter (not 2
column22: and it\\\'s clear what you\\\'re going to get back based on the function name.  This reduces the possibility that a programmer would pass in an irrelevant value for $type
column23: like "occurrence." This reduced code and enforced a tighter contract between functions. (More on Design by Contract: url  I made the changes to the tests
column24: and committed this in cc06e9dd954e24aca4ec3533823bb8bd6b81027f This change will require changes to how you call these functions in this insight. I\\\'ll review that separately.\''
